children: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated for a pigmented skin lesion that has expanded in diameter over 6 months.
The skin lesion is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common variant of malignant melanoma. It presents as a well-defined, asymmetric patch or plaque with an irregular border and variation in color, and initially spreads horizontally. Most skin cancers occur on sun-exposed skin, but superficial spreading melanoma tends to occur on the back in men and the legs in women (areas that receive intermittent sun exposure and are prone to sunburn).
A 73-year-old woman is evaluated for diminished vision in her right eye. The patient has a history compatible with previously undiagnosed and untreated giant cell arteritis.
Funduscopic findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is optic disc atrophy, which is characterized by pallor and flatness of the optic disc. Optic disc atrophy results from damage to the nerve fiber layer of the retina, optic nerve, optic chiasm, or optic tracts. With progressive loss of neurons, the optic disc becomes pale; with extensive damage, the optic disc becomes white. A normal appearing optic disc is pink in color, as
shown

. In younger patients, the most common cause of optic nerve atrophy is optic neuritis; in older patients, ischemic optic neuropathy is the most common etiology. This older patient with a history compatible with previously undiagnosed and untreated giant cell arteritis most likely has ischemic optic atrophy.
A 71-year-old man is evaluated for several growths on his skin that have increased in number as he ages.
A representative skin lesion is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is seborrheic keratosis. Seborrheic keratoses are common, benign neoplasms that present as tan or brown-to-black, well-demarcated, "stuck-on"–appearing lesions with waxy surfaces and horn cysts (dark keratin plugs). The number of seborrheic keratoses can vary from an isolated lesion to hundreds, and they are commonly located on the trunk, face, and upper extremities. A "Christmas tree" pattern (Blaschko lines distribution) may be seen on the back.
A 78-year-old man is evaluated for a wound on his
lower leg
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Venous stasis ulcers commonly occur on the lower extremities in the area from the midcalf to the ankle; can be single or multiple; are typically irregularly shaped and shallow; and often weep serous fluid. They are associated with signs of chronic venous insufficiency, such as edema, varicosities, eczematous changes, brown pigmentation from hemosiderin deposition, lipodermatosclerosis (fibrosis of subcutaneous tissue), atrophie blanche (pale plaques of scar tissue), and evidence of healed ulcers. These types of ulcers account for up to 70% of all leg ulcers. Diagnosis is usually made clinically.
A 40-year-old man is evaluated for a
dystrophic toenail
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Onychomycosis is a common dermatophytosis of the nail. Toenails are most commonly affected, and distal subungual onychomycosis is the most common pattern. The distal nail plate becomes discolored (yellow, white, or brown) and thickened. Under the nail plate, there is an accumulation of subungual debris, resulting in separation of the nail plate from the nail bed (onycholysis). Onychomycosis can be seen in association with diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, or immunosuppression; skin conditions such as tinea pedis; and poor nail hygiene. Confirmation of infection with potassium hydroxide preparation, periodic acid-Schiff staining, or fungal culture should be done before treatment to rule out psoriasis or traumatic nail changes.

title: Question 6

children: A 46-year-old woman with long-standing osteoarthritis of the left knee associated with a large effusion develops acute calf pain. Three days later, this skin finding is
noted
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has a ruptured popliteal (Baker) cyst. This picture demonstrates the “crescent sign,” an ecchymotic area below the medial malleolus, that suggests cyst rupture. A popliteal cyst is a benign swelling of the synovial bursa behind the knee joint; synovial fluid fills the cyst. Popliteal cysts most commonly develop in the setting of knee trauma, osteoarthritis, or inflammatory arthritis, but can occur in patients without joint disease. They are frequently asymptomatic but can present with posterior knee pain and swelling. In rare instances, cysts may cause compression of adjacent structures, leading to compression syndrome, posterior tibial nerve entrapment, or popliteal artery occlusion. Ruptured cysts may mimic deep venous thromboses (pseudothrombophlebitis) and may be associated with ecchymosis from the popliteal fossa to the ankle. In patients with asymptomatic popliteal cysts, no treatment is necessary. Symptomatic patients often experience relief with joint aspiration and intra-articular glucocorticoid injection. Pseudothrombophlebitis can be treated with rest, elevation, and NSAIDs. The posterior view of a different patient
demonstrates
a popliteal cyst in the calf of the left leg and is most prominent with the patient standing and the knee fully extended.

figureCredits: Image in the stem reproduced with permission from Moore G. Atlas of the Musculoskeletal Examination. Philadelphia, PA: American College of Physicians; 2003. Copyright 2003, American College of Physicians.

title: Question 7

children: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for vulvar and perianal pruritus and dyspareunia.
Vulva findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has anogenital lichen sclerosus. Anogenital lichen sclerosus is a chronic dermatitis characterized by atrophic white plaques or papules extending over the perineum and around the anus in a figure 8 or “keyhole” configuration. Lesions may also be purpuric, hyperkeratotic, bullous, or ulcerated. Common symptoms include itching, dysuria, and dyspareunia. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy. Women with lichen sclerosus are at increased risk for squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 29-year-old man is evaluated for diffuse erythema of the
skin
that occurred after a few minutes of exposure to sunlight.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Photosensitivity disorder is the most likely diagnosis. The sparing of the area that was photo-protected by a wristwatch helps establish this diagnosis. Photosensitivity disorders are characterized by an abnormal skin response following exposure to ultraviolet radiation. They are often categorized as idiopathic or related to the application or ingestion of an external agent, such as topical application of an agent or drug ingestion. Photosensitivity reactions related to exogenous agents are phototoxic or photoallergic. Phototoxicity can occur in anyone with a threshold concentration of the responsible chemical or drug and is more common than photoallergy. Phototoxic reactions present as an exaggerated sunburn within minutes to hours of sun exposure. Photoallergy is a cell-mediated immune response found in previously sensitized individuals and can be elicited by re-exposure to small amounts of offending agent. Photoallergic reactions occur more commonly after topical exposure of a sensitizing agent and presents as pruritic, eczematous eruptions within 24 to 48 hours after sun exposure. A history of culprit drug ingestion or topical applications of a sensitizer and the timing of the reaction after sun exposure help differentiate between idiopathic, phototoxic, and photoallergic disorders.

Porphyria cutanea tarda typically involves the dorsum of the hands, although other areas may also be affected. Erythroderma, although it resembles a sunburn, is not limited to sun-exposed areas as is the case with this patient.
A 22-year-old woman is evaluated for a changing mole, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's skin finding is most consistent with a halo nevus, which is a benign melanocytic nevus surrounded by a round “halo” of hypopigmentation or depigmentation. The lesion has three stages. In the first stage, there is pigment loss, which usually lasts months, and often heralds the regression of the nevus. The second stage is the regression of the nevus, which usually lasts years. In the third stage, there is repigmentation of the halo. It is commonly found on the upper back of adolescents and young adults.
A 45-year-old woman has chronic plaque psoriasis. She recently stopped taking glucocorticoids to treat an asthma exacerbation and has developed the new generalized skin condition
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Generalized pustular psoriasis is most commonly recognized as creamy white pustules on an erythematous base that coalesce to form lakes of pus. These lesions may rupture, leaving large, eroded areas. This condition can be life-threatening and frequently occurs following withdrawal of systemic glucocorticoids.
A 73-year-old man heard a popping sound and developed pain in his right arm immediately after throwing a ball.
Arm findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is a biceps tendon rupture. Acute proximal biceps tendon rupture often follows a traumatic event and is associated with a "pop" and pain, followed by ecchymosis and swelling. Some biceps tendon ruptures, however, may not be preceded by a traumatic event but instead occur gradually. Swelling of the biceps belly, known as Popeye sign, may appear. The Popeye sign may not be noticed in patients with reduced muscle mass or obesity.
A 50-year-old woman is evaluated for an asymptomatic, soft growth on the back of the neck, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Acrochordons (skin tags) are soft, pedunculated, fleshy, benign papules that occur on the sides and back of the neck, axillae, inframammary region, groin, and buttocks. They may be caused by friction or increased concentrations of insulin or insulin-like growth factors; acrochordons are often seen in patients with diabetes mellitus or obesity. A familial predisposition may also be associated with these lesions.
A 41-year-old woman is evaluated for an expanding slightly pruritic rash with scaling, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Tinea (dermatophytosis) is classified based on the body site that is involved: tinea pedis (“athlete's foot”), tinea manuum (hand), tinea cruris (perineum), tinea capitis (scalp), tinea faciei (face), and tinea corporis (the body, excluding the genital area or inguinal folds). Tinea corporis manifests with the characteristic annular lesion with a slight scale; an erythematous, advancing edge; and central clearing. Pityriasis versicolor presents with oval macules with minimal scaling that may be hypo- or hyperpigmented. Granuloma annulare may have a similar appearance to tinea corporis, but scaling is not present.
A 55-year-old man is evaluated for slowly progressive changes in his left hand, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Dupuytren contracture, which is characterized by progressive fibrosis of the palmar fascia. Loss of full extension develops slowly over decades with finger flexion contractures. The earliest sign is “puckering” of the skin over the flexor tendon in the palm. The cause is unknown, but Dupuytren contracture is associated with occupations involving repetitive motion or vibration; conditions such as diabetes mellitus or complex regional pain syndrome; alcohol use disorder; and cigarette smoking.
A 29-year-old woman is evaluated for a chronic skin lesion on the anterior surface of her right leg, as
shown
. It is firm to palpation and forms a “dimple” when the sides are compressed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Dermatofibromas, or fibrous histiocytomas, are benign skin lesions that appear as firm dermal nodules about the size of a pencil eraser; they are associated with a dimple when the lateral sides are pinched together, as
shown
. They are typically found on the lower extremities and are more common in women. They are usually asymptomatic or cause only minor itching.
A 69-year-old man is evaluated for numerous unsightly, rough lesions on the dorsum of his
hands
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Actinic keratoses are precancerous lesions (
arrows
) that can develop into invasive squamous cell
carcinoma

. They typically present clinically in sun-exposed areas as erythematous lesions with overlying hyperkeratosis that are often scaly to touch. Actinic keratoses may be easier to feel than to see, making palpation a key element of the physical examination. In contrast, seborrheic keratoses are pigmented lesions with a “stuck-on” appearance. Superficial basal cell carcinoma may resemble actinic keratoses but appear as a pink-red patch, often with a slight thread-like pearly border.
A patient is evaluated for a skin condition that reappears at the same location each time the patient is exposed to a sulfa-containing drug. The patient's posterior neck is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient's skin finding is most compatible with a fixed drug eruption, in which one or more erythematous or violaceous annular lesions recur in the same location(s) with each re-exposure to the offending drug. The lesions resolve with hyperpigmentation.
A 71-year-old woman is evaluated for a chronic deformity of the left great toe associated with occasional pain. No other joints are involved.
The toe is
shown
during a painful episode.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has a bunion (hallux). Bunion deformity is diagnosed clinically as a lateral deviation of the great toe at the first metatarsal. The nail of the toe may also face medially secondary to rotation of the toe. Bunions can lead to pain, first metatarsal phalangeal joint osteoarthritis, and bursitis characterized by erythema and warmth overlying the joint, as seen in this patient.
A 58-year-old woman is evaluated for vaginal burning and dyspareunia.
Findings of the external genitalia and vaginal introitus (
arrow
) are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has vulvovaginal atrophy that is associated with the genitourinary syndrome of menopause. Classic vulvar and vaginal findings include shiny, smooth, and dry vaginal epithelium with loss of rugae. Inflammatory changes may include erythema and petechiae. Patients with vulvovaginal atrophy may also have sparse pubic hair and introital narrowing. Patients typically note vaginal burning or irritation; sexual symptoms, such as dyspareunia or sexual dysfunction; or urinary symptoms, such as dysuria or recurrent urinary infections. These symptoms are the result of estrogen deficiency.
A 71-year-old man reports progressive vision loss over several years.
Retinal findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is age-related macular degeneration (AMD). This patient has distinct yellow-white lesions surrounding the macular area (drusen) and areas of pigment mottling characteristic of dry AMD. AMD is a progressive chronic disease involving the central retina. Patients with early AMD are often asymptomatic, although yellow drusen may be visible underneath retinal pigment epithelium. Patients with atrophic (dry) AMD, which accounts for 80% to 90% of AMD cases, note slowly progressive vision loss over the course of years. About 10% to 20% of patients with atrophic AMD progress to neovascular (wet) AMD, which often presents with more rapid visual loss and may be accompanied by a sudden worsening of central vision associated with straight-line distortion (metamorphopsia), scotoma, or both.
A 44-year-old woman is evaluated for the abrupt appearance of painful skin nodules following an episode of infectious diarrhea. She also reports fever and arthralgia.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis (Sweet syndrome). Individual skin lesions are tender, nonpruritic, brightly erythematous, well-demarcated papules and plaques that appear on the face, neck, and extremities. In addition to the skin eruption, patients typically have high fevers, leukocytosis with a left shift, and elevated inflammatory markers, and often muscle or joint pain.

Sweet syndrome may be idiopathic, but most cases typically develop after an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection or in the setting of hematologic abnormalities, particularly myelodysplastic syndrome and myelodysplastic syndrome evolving into acute myeloid leukemia.

objective.__html: Diagnose acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis (Sweet syndrome).

children: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated for an acute blistering skin condition that does not involve mucosal surfaces.
Representative skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is bullous pemphigoid, which is a chronic, autoimmune vesiculobullous eruption that predominantly involves nonmucosal surfaces. It is characterized by subepidermal vesicles and blisters that are tense and do not rupture easily. Urticarial lesions may precede the onset of blistering. Bullous pemphigoid is usually widespread. Sites of predilection include the lower abdomen, inner thighs, groin, axillae, and flexural aspects of the arms and legs. Pemphigus vulgaris tends to involve oral and vaginal mucosa. Porphyria cutanea tarda usually involves sun-exposed areas, such as the dorsum of the hands.
A 22-year-old woman has a chronic pruritic skin condition on the trunk and legs.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Nummular eczema is characterized by extremely pruritic round or oval patches of eczematous dermatitis consisting of papules, scaling, crusting, and often serous oozing. Most lesions appear on the trunk and legs and are 2 to 10 cm in diameter. In contrast, discoid lupus tends to appear on sun-exposed areas rather than the trunk. In addition, discoid lupus typically presents as hypo- or hyperpigmented patches or plaques, with erythema during active disease, which may be variably atrophic or hyperkeratotic.
A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for a pigmented lesion on her face, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Lentigo maligna begins as a uniformly pigmented, light-brown patch on the face or upper trunk that is confined to the epidermis and as such is an in situ melanoma. Over time, the lesion expands and becomes more variegated in color. Lentigo maligna melanoma is the term applied to a lentigo maligna that has invaded the dermis. Biopsy is necessary to differentiate lentigo maligna from lentigo maligna melanoma. In both in situ and invasive forms, melanoma cells extend far beyond the clinically apparent borders of the lesion.
A 30-year-old man is evaluated for an acute pruritic skin eruption.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is allergic contact dermatitis, which is typically intensely pruritic. In acute reactions, the skin is red, edematous, weepy, and crusted; there may be vesicles or bullae. The pattern (round, square, linear) and location of the eruption often provide clues to the source of the allergen, such as linear patterns from brushing an arm against poison ivy.
A 35-year-old man is evaluated for loss of peripheral vision discovered during a comprehensive ophthalmologic examination. The patient is asymptomatic and has 20/20 visual acuity in both eyes.
Funduscopic findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is glaucoma. This fundoscopic image shows a relatively large cup-to-disc ratio of >0.5 and cupping, identified by the disappearance of vessels over the edge of the attenuated optic rim. The normal optic disc is slightly oval in the vertical meridian and is pink in color, as
shown
. A central depression on the surface of the disc is called the physiological cup. Typically, this cup-to-disc ratio is less than 0.5. The optic discs of the eyes should appear similar and symmetric.

Funduscopic findings in glaucoma include vertical extension of the central cup, disc hemorrhages, and an increased optic cup-to-disc ratio (>0.5). All of these findings are nonspecific, however, and may be seen in patients without glaucoma. Glaucoma is the leading cause of permanent blindness in the world. It is typically characterized by increased intraocular pressure as a result of decreased outflow of aqueous humor from the anterior chamber. If central vision is not lost, patients can maintain normal visual acuity, potentially delaying diagnosis.
A 74-year-old man is evaluated for the pruritic skin changes on his bilateral lower extremities, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Xerotic eczema (also called asteatotic eczema, winter itch, or eczema craquelé) usually occurs on the anterior shins of older persons with dry skin. Affected skin is often red, invariably dry, and cracked, with multiple fine fissures that resemble cracks in porcelain, also described as a "dried riverbed" appearance. The dermatitis is an isolated finding more common in winter or in dry conditions. Aging is the most common cause; rarely, it may occur in association with an underlying condition, such as malnutrition, hypothyroidism, and malignancy, or as an adverse effect of certain drugs (e.g., retinoids, diuretics, antineoplastic agents).
A 23-year-old man is evaluated for a chronic skin condition, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has acne vulgaris, or common acne. Acne vulgaris is characterized by noninflammatory and inflammatory lesions. Noninflammatory lesions are comedones that can be open (blackheads) or closed (whiteheads). Red papules and pustules are inflammatory lesions. This patient has severe inflammatory acne with papules and pustules, large open comedones, marked postinflammatory erythema, and a few atrophic scars.
A 45-year-old man develops a generalized painful skin rash 4 weeks after starting allopurinol for recurrent gout. He is systemically ill with fever, malaise, and facial swelling.
The rash on his thigh is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DIHS), a severe life-threatening medication reaction. Symptoms begin with fever and flulike symptoms, quickly followed by burning skin pain and rash. Patients typically develop a morbilliform exanthem that starts on the face and upper trunk and spreads distally. Eventually the patient develops striking facial edema and redness, a hallmark of DIHS. Oral mucosal involvement is common. Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) is also a widely used term for DIHS. The most common medications that cause DIHS include sulfonamide antibiotics, allopurinol, and anticonvulsants. Unlike other severe medication reactions, the onset of symptoms is delayed, often 2 to 6 weeks following exposure.
A 56-year-old woman is evaluated for recurrent epistaxis and obscure gastrointestinal bleeding.
Physical examination findings on her face are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Examination of this patient's face and lips reveals the characteristic arteriovenous malformations of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu disease). This autosomal dominant disorder is commonly associated with epistaxis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and iron deficiency anemia. Other systemic manifestations include arteriovenous malformations in the pulmonary, hepatic, and cerebral circulations.
A 70-year-old man is evaluated for a slowly growing lesion on his
chin
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is basal cell carcinoma (BCC), of which the most common type is nodular BCC. Nodular lesions are pearly and pink with telangiectatic vessels and may have a central depression; ulceration and crusting can occur. Flecks of melanin pigment may be present.
A 47-year-old woman has a chronic skin condition involving the extensor surfaces of her knees, elbows, sacrum, and scalp.
A representative lesion is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Psoriasis vulgaris is most commonly characterized by sharply marginated plaques with a thick, adherent, silvery scale. Psoriasis has a predilection for the extensor areas of elbows, knees, presacral skin, and scalp. The disease can be limited or widespread.
A 40-year-old woman is evaluated for progressive changes in the skin pigmentation of her face, as
shown
. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is melasma, also known as chloasma, or “the mask of pregnancy.” Melasma is a commonly acquired condition resulting in patchy hyperpigmentation of the skin on the face. It can also be seen on the upper extremities. Clinically, it presents as ill-defined, tan to dark brown, reticulated patches mostly on the sun-exposed areas of the face (malar, mandibular, and centrofacial regions), and worsens with further sun-exposure.

In this condition, melanocytes overproduce melanin due to a multitude of factors, including ultraviolet radiation exposure, genetic predisposition, and hormonal influence (pregnancy, use of oral contraceptives). Melasma often fades during the postpartum period, with sun protection, and upon discontinuation of oral contraceptives; however, it may take months to years for pigmentation to normalize. Women and individuals with darker skin types are more commonly predisposed.

title: Question 34

children: A 26-year-old man is evaluated for hindfoot pain that occurs with taking his first few steps in the morning. Point tenderness to palpation is present, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is plantar fasciitis. Diagnosis is based on demonstrating palpable tenderness at the anterior base of the calcaneus (medial calcaneal tubercle), as indicated in the image. The windlass test assesses for pain in the plantar fascia by simulating the motion of a step. With the patient's foot bearing weight, the toes are dorsiflexed by the examiner, maximally stretching the plantar fascia. A windlass test that reproduces the foot pain has a high specificity for plantar fasciitis. A calcaneal stress fracture would be suggested by pain that is more posterior on the calcaneus and which does not improve with walking. Tarsal tunnel syndrome may be associated with a positive Tinel sign with tapping on the tunnel posterior to the medical malleolus.

figureCredits: Image reproduced with permission from Moore G. Atlas of the Musculoskeletal Examination. Philadelphia, PA: American College of Physicians; 2003. Copyright 2003, American College of Physicians.

children: A 23-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with the skin condition
shown
. The skin lesions involve less than 10% of the body surface area. She was recently started on carbamazepine for epilepsy.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Skin lesions of SJS appear as annular erythematous macules or papules, often with a dusky center and rim of bright erythema (targetoid lesions), that may progress to papules or plaques with central bullae. Lesions may coalesce and progress to epidermal necrosis and sloughing, leaving behind moist, erythematous, exposed dermis.

SJS and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are related clinical syndromes characterized by acute epidermal necrosis. The classification of SJS and TEN is determined by the percentage of body surface area with epidermal detachment: SJS involves less than 10%, SJS/TEN overlap involves 10% to 30%, and TEN involves greater than 30%. SJS begins with a prodrome that may include fever, respiratory symptoms, headache, vomiting, and/or diarrhea, followed 1 to 14 days later by the onset of cutaneous lesions and involvement of mucous membranes.

Essentially all cases of TEN are temporally correlated with medications, whereas about 75% of SJS cases are caused by drug exposure; the remaining cases are related to infection or vaccination. HIV infection, kidney disease, uncontrolled autoimmune disease, and human leukocyte antigen type (HLA-B*1502 and HLA-B*5801) also contribute to increased risk.
A patient is evaluated for new-onset redness and irritation in the
right eye
without pain. He notes significant watery discharge. Visual acuity and pupillary reflexes are normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is viral conjunctivitis, which typically presents as unilateral, painless, diffuse redness of the eye associated with a watery or mucoserous discharge. On closer examination, inflamed and dilated (injected) conjunctival blood vessels are
seen
, with mild crusting at the lateral commissure and inferior eyelid. Inspection of the retracted lower eyelid may also show a follicular (“bumpy”) appearance of the lid (tarsal) conjunctiva.

Viral conjunctivitis may occur as part of a viral prodrome, followed by adenopathy, fever, pharyngitis, and other symptoms and signs of upper respiratory tract infection; however, eye involvement may also be the only manifestation of viral infection. Patients may report a burning or gritty sensation in one eye and may believe that a mucoserous discharge represents a bacterial infection. Blurred vision may be present secondary to tearing in these patients, but visual acuity and pupillary reflexes are typically normal. Viral conjunctivitis tends to be highly infectious, commonly spreading to the other eye within 2 days. It is a self-limited process that resolves similarly to the common cold, with gradual resolution over several days without specific treatment.
A 27-year-old woman is evaluated for malodorous vaginal discharge.
Vaginal wet mount findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is bacterial vaginosis. This image
shows
clue cells, which are vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria that obscure the cell borders (
arrow

) and which suggest bacterial vaginosis. Bacterial vaginosis is the most common cause of vaginal discharge. It results from the loss of the normal hydrogen peroxide–producing lactobacilli in the vagina with an increase in the vaginal pH that contributes to an overgrowth of
Gardnerella vaginalis

and other anaerobes. Anaerobic overgrowth results in the production of amines, causing the characteristically malodorous discharge. Clinical diagnosis includes the presence of at least three of four features: vaginal pH greater than 4.5; thin and homogeneous vaginal discharge; a positive whiff test result in which application of 10% potassium hydroxide to vaginal secretions results in a fishy odor; and the presence of at least 20% clue cells on saline wet mount preparation.
A 42-year-old man is evaluated for a chronic pruritic
skin rash
involving the groin.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Tinea cruris, a dermatophyte infection of the groin, pubic region, and thighs, manifests with an erythematous, well-demarcated edge; an annular lesion with a slight scale; and incomplete central clearing. Tinea can be suspected based on clinical presentation and pruritus; however, diagnosis is based on visualization by microscopic examination of branching hyphae in the keratin (scale) using a potassium hydroxide preparation.
An elderly hospitalized patient is evaluated for a
pressure injury
Which of the following is the most likely stage of the pressure injury shown?

This patient has a stage II pressure injury. This patient has evidence of bruising and ulceration, which is beyond the nonblanchable redness characteristic of a stage I injury and is most compatible with stage II pressure injury. Pressure injuries (or pressure ulcers) represent damage to the skin and underlying tissue caused by unrelieved pressure. Pressure injuries may be classified with the use of a
staging system
; advanced stages are characterized by increasing tissue loss, depth, and ulcer size.
Pressure Injury Staging System
Stage of Pressure Injury
Description
I
Intact skin with nonblanchable redness
II
Partial-thickness loss of dermis; shallow open ulcer with red-pink wound bed without slough
May also present as intact or ruptured serum-filled blister
III
Full-thickness tissue loss; visible subcutaneous fat but not bone, tendon, or muscle
May include undermining or tunneling
IV
Full-thickness tissue loss with exposed bone, tendon, or muscle
Unstageable
Full-thickness tissue loss in which base of the ulcer is covered by slough or eschar
Suspected deep-tissue injury
Purple or maroon localized area of discolored but intact skin, or blood-filled blister caused by damage of underlying soft tissue from pressure or shear

footnotes: Information from Edsberg LE, Black JM, Goldberg M, et al. Revised National Pressure Ulcer Advisory Panel pressure injury staging system: revised pressure injury staging system. J Wound Ostomy Continence Nurs. 2016;43:585-97.

children: A 76-year-old man is evaluated for this chronic, hard, and asymptomatic skin
protrusion
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A cutaneous horn is an exophytic keratotic lesion that forms on the surface of the skin and can be associated with benign, premalignant, or malignant skin lesions. It is usually conical, cylindrical, or pointed and is often found over sun-exposed areas. Excisional biopsy of the horn and underlying skin is frequently recommended.

title: Question 41

children: A 46-year-old woman is evaluated for postcoital bleeding. A speculum examination of the
cervix
is performed.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has an erosive cervical lesion that is most consistent with carcinoma of the cervix. The most common signs of cervical cancer are vaginal bleeding between menstrual periods or after menopause, postcoital vaginal bleeding, and abnormal vaginal discharge. Direct examination usually shows an abnormal cervix, although a tumor in the cervical canal may be difficult to see. The diagnosis is usually established by punch biopsy of obvious lesions or by colposcopy with directed biopsy.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 31-year-old man is evaluated for the acute onset of an extremely pruritic generalized rash. The lesions last 1 to 2 hours, but new lesions develop at other sites.
Representative lesions are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Urticaria presents as episodes of itchy, erythematous raised lesions with sharp borders that can last from minutes to hours. Some urticarial lesions may have dusky or pale centers and may be mistaken for the targetoid lesions of erythema multiforme. Wheals can be multiple or isolated and usually involve the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles.
A 37-year-old woman is evaluated for severely pruritic papules that appeared this morning,
Representative skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is bed bug bites. Lesions often occur in a series ("breakfast, lunch, and dinner"), as seen in this patient, on exposed sites, such as the face, neck, arms, and hands. The lesions are painless but pruritic and appear as urticaria-like papules with a central hemorrhagic punctum.
Cimex lectularius
and
Cimex hemipterus
(bed bugs) are nocturnal insects that appear as
shown
. They typically hide in cracks and crevices, especially in mattresses, cushions, and bed frames, during the day and bite at night.
A 53-year-old woman is evaluated for acute onset of
lower extremity
pain.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The patient's lower extremity findings are most consistent with chronic venous insufficiency and stasis dermatitis. This patient has evidence of chronic vascular congestion, as seen by the "sock sign," a circumferential indentation on the right lower extremity caused by compression of edema by the elastic band in socks. Other changes consistent with chronic venous insufficiency demonstrated in this image include erythema, areas of hyperpigmentation, and trophic skin changes at the upper portion of the calves. Chronic venous insufficiency usually results from incompetence of venous valves in the lower extremities, causing hypertension in dependent areas and leading to increased vascular permeability, edema, and the release of inflammatory mediators. Stasis dermatitis is a late manifestation of chronic venous disease and usually presents with scaling and eczematous patches that, when acutely inflamed, may weep and crust; this makes it difficult to differentiate stasis dermatitis from bacterial superinfection. Early stasis dermatitis is most commonly confused with cellulitis but is a significantly more likely diagnosis than cellulitis in patients presenting with bilateral erythema and swelling of the legs.
A 53-year-old man is evaluated for gradual loss of vision.
Ocular findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is a cataract, recognized as any opacification of the otherwise optically clear lens behind the pupil and iris. Cataracts should be suspected in patients presenting with painless gradual worsening of visual acuity. Glare sensitivity and vision impairment may be especially noticeable at night. In addition to lens opacification, direct ophthalmoscopy will show a diminished red reflex, and obscured funduscopic examination. Cataracts are the most common cause of blindness and visual impairment worldwide.
A 45-year-old man who works in food preparation is evaluated for a chronic skin condition confined to the palmar surfaces of his hands.
The left hand is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is hand dermatitis, which is characterized by pruritic, erythematous plaques on the palmar and dorsal hands and can lead to fissuring and lichenification over time. Hand dermatitis often results from a combination of causes, such as excessive hand washing, contact dermatitis, atopic dermatitis, or dyshidrotic eczema (pompholyx). It is commonly seen in patients who have jobs involving frequent or prolonged exposure to water, chemicals, and occlusive gloves (health care, house cleaning, food preparation, hairstyling).
A 71-year-old woman is evaluated for right-sided hip pain that is worse with walking and when sleeping on her right side. The patient is able to localize the pain, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS; formerly known as trochanteric bursitis). Lateral hip pain is most commonly caused by GTPS or meralgia paresthetica. Pain that worsens with lying on the affected side suggests GTPS; the pain may also radiate to the buttock or knee if the iliotibial band is also affected. Pain also commonly occurs with walking, prolonged standing, and climbing stairs. Patients may often localize the pain by pointing with one finger over the greater trochanter. The most common examination finding in GTPS is tenderness to palpation of the greater trochanter. Pain secondary to hip arthritis is more commonly felt in the anterior region of the hip and groin.

title: Question 48

children: A 40-year-old woman is evaluated for acute eye pain associated with painful eye movement and diminished visual acuity.
Eye findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient most likely has orbital cellulitis, characterized by periorbital erythema, warmth, and pain. Orbital cellulitis can be distinguished from preseptal cellulitis (periorbital cellulitis) by the presence of pain with eye movements, ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, and vision impairment as orbital cellulitis involves the extraocular muscle and fatty tissue whereas preseptal cellulitis does not. The diagnosis of orbital cellulitis is suspected clinically and can be confirmed by CT of the orbits and sinuses.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

title: Question 49

children: A 23-year-old woman has a 7-month history of a pruritic rash on the flexural surfaces of her wrists, arms, and legs. The patient was recently diagnosed with hepatitis C virus infection.
The rash on her thigh is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Lichen planus (LP) is an inflammatory skin disorder that can affect the skin, mucous membranes, scalp, and/or nails. The hallmark lesion of LP is a pruritic, purple, polygonal papule; these papules are usually distributed symmetrically on the wrists, flexural aspects of the arms and legs, lower back, and genitals. The papules are small and may be isolated or grouped together; they often develop along lines of prior trauma. A reticulated network of white lines (Wickham striae) may be visible on the surface of the papules, as
shown

in a different patient, particularly if moistened. The face, palms, and soles are usually spared; however, mucous membranes, including the lips, mouth, and vulva, are commonly involved. LP occurs with increased frequency in patients with liver disease, particularly hepatitis C virus infection, although the reasons for this are unclear.

figureCredits: Image in the stem reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 31-year old man is evaluated for increased skin fragility involving the face, scalp, and dorsal hands, as
shown
. The patient has risk factors for hepatitis C virus infection.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), a hereditary or acquired blistering disease caused by excess circulating porphyrins. Patients present with vesicles, bullae, and skin fragility on sun-exposed skin, most commonly on the face, dorsal hands (as seen in this patient), and scalp; photosensitivity is the hallmark of the disease. Other features include hyperpigmentation, milia (tiny inclusion cysts), hypertrichosis, and alopecia. Up to 50% of patients with sporadic PCT have hepatitis C virus infection.

title: Question 51

children: A 31-year-old woman is evaluated for the recent onset of an asymptomatic rash, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Tinea versicolor (pityriasis versicolor) is characterized by slightly scaly hyper- or hypopigmented macules and patches of the upper trunk and upper arms. The causative yeast organism,
Malassezia furfur

, is a normal inhabitant of the skin; however, when hot and humid environmental conditions favor its growth, symptoms appear. Diagnosis is confirmed by microscopic evaluation of a potassium hydroxide preparation made from scrapings of lesions. The preparation
shown
demonstrates the classic appearance of both spores and hyphae in a "spaghetti and meatball" pattern.

figureCredits: Image in the stem reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for a slowly growing skin lesion on her back, as
shown
. Originally, the lesion was flat but has gradually changed to its current morphology.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Nodular melanomas often present as dark blue or black, "berry-like" lesions that most commonly originate from normal skin, but can also arise from a preexisting nevus. Nodular melanoma is often aggressive and invades deep into the skin layers early because it expands vertically rather than horizontally. Depth of invasion is the single most important prognostic determinant.

title: Question 53

children: A 25-year-old woman presents with vaginal discharge and itching and dysuria.
A vaginal wet mount is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Trichomoniasis is the diagnosis, as motile trichomonads (
arrow
) are
seen

on this vaginal wet mount. Trichomonads are slightly larger than leukocytes, are usually oval or pear shaped, and have flagella. Women with trichomoniasis may be asymptomatic or present with copious vaginal discharge that is malodorous, pale yellow or gray, frothy, and associated with vulvar itching and burning. Microscopy with examination of a wet mount can establish the diagnosis when positive, but false-negative test results are common. Nucleic acid amplification testing or rapid antigen testing may be used as the primary diagnostic test or if the suspicion of trichomoniasis is high but the wet mount result is negative.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 23-year-old man presents with acute onset of a right
red eye
and discharge.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis, as demonstrated by the copious purulent discharge seen in the image. Hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by an abrupt onset and extensive purulent discharge. It is usually associated with gonococcal infection in a sexually active adolescent or adult. It is vision threatening, and emergent ophthalmology referral is necessary. Keratitis, iritis, and scleritis typically do not cause copious purulent drainage.
A 45-year-old man is evaluated for a 3-week history of elbow pain. He works as a computer programmer. The patient is able to localize the
elbow pain
. Range of motion is normal, but pain worsens with forced extension of the wrist.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow), which is caused by overuse of the wrist extensor muscles. The pain is located laterally, with localized tenderness over the lateral epicondyle. Pain characteristically radiates down the forearm to the dorsal hand, and worsens with activity and at night. On examination, there is tenderness to palpation where the extensor muscles attach to the lateral epicondyle. Pain increases with forced extension of the wrist.
A 32-year-old man develops a rash on his hands following an episode of herpes labialis.
The rash is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is erythema multiforme (EM), an immune-mediated condition that can be recognized by its classic targetoid plaques. The sharply defined plaques feature two differently colored concentric rings (a pale inner ring and a red outer ring) surrounding a pale, dusky, vesiculated or crusted center. These plaques typically appear on the face and acral sites. Mucosal lesions are present in up to 70% of patients. Crops of lesions persist for approximately 7 days and resolve without scarring.

Most cases of EM are caused by infections, with herpes simplex viruses 1 and 2 being the most common. Drug-induced cases of EM are less frequent and typically result from NSAIDs, antiepileptic agents, or sulfonamides.
A 42-year-old man is evaluated for chronic left ear pain and discharge associated with decreased hearing.
Otoscopic findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a cholesteatoma. The otoscopic findings
show
an opaque, perforated tympanic membrane (
black arrow
) with drainage into the external ear canal along with a white mass visible in the middle ear canal consistent with a cholesteatoma (
red arrow

). In patients without perforation, a cholesteatoma may appear as a subtle whitish discoloration behind an otherwise normal tympanic membrane. A cholesteatoma is a collection of keratinized, desquamated epithelial cells in the middle ear or mastoid, although it does not contain cholesterol or lipids; it is not a neoplasm. Cholesteatomas are usually caused by eustachian tube dysfunction that results in tympanic membrane retraction and inflammatory changes in a pocket behind the retracted membrane. Epithelial debris accumulates in this pocket, grows with continued inflammation and infection, and may eventually erode into middle ear or mastoid structures.

title: Question 58

children: A 20-year-old man is evaluated for changes in his skin pigment without
textural changes
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is vitiligo, a common acquired autoimmune condition characterized by the loss of function or absence of melanocytes. Clinically, it appears as completely depigmented, well-demarcated symmetric macules or patches with no scale. Its onset is insidious and asymptomatic, starting as small macules that gradually enlarge. The most commonly affected areas are the extensor surfaces, such as the dorsal hands and feet, elbows, and knees, and the periorificial areas, such as around the mouth, eyes, rectum, and genitals. Vitiligo can occur at any age and affects both sexes equally. It may be associated with other autoimmune conditions, such as type 1 diabetes mellitus and thyroid disease.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 37-year-old woman is evaluated for acne that developed as an adult. She also has episodes of skin flushing in response to eating spicy foods.
Facial findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is rosacea, which is characterized by persistent central facial redness that primarily involves the convex surfaces and spares the periocular skin. Telangiectasias, pink papules, pustules, nodules, or ocular disease may also be present, but comedones are not seen. Flushing that lasts longer than 10 minutes in response to a variety of triggers, such as heat, cold, exercise, embarrassment, red wine, or spicy foods, provides supportive historical evidence. Acne vulgaris is not associated with the flushing evident in this patient. Although seborrheic dermatitis may involve the cheeks, it consists of yellow scaly patches on an erythematous base rather than the findings seen in this image.

title: Question 60

children: A 21-year-old man is evaluated for pharyngitis and a rash.
Examination findings of the throat and
arm
are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient most likely has pharyngitis, which presents as sore throat that may worsen with swallowing; symptoms typically last less than 1 week. Physical examination findings that support the diagnosis of streptococcal pharyngitis include palatal petechiae and a scarlatiniform rash, as seen in this patient, and a strawberry tongue.
Features suggesting the more common viral cause include cough, conjunctivitis, coryza, hoarseness, and oral ulcers. Only 5% to 15% of pharyngitis cases are caused by bacteria, most often group A
Streptococcus pyogenes.

The Infectious Diseases Society of America suggests that patients with two or fewer Centor criteria (fever by history, tonsillar exudates, tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, and absence of cough) do not need to be tested. Patients with three or more Centor criteria should be tested by using a rapid antigen detection test.

figureCredits: Images reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for a slowly evolving lesion on the dorsal aspect of the left arm.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma. As in this case, cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma presents as a slowly evolving, isolated keratotic or eroded macule, papule, or nodule that commonly appears on the sun-exposed skin, including the face, scalp, neck, pinna, lip, or extremities. In contrast, a basal cell carcinoma most commonly demonstrates a heaped-up waxy or pearly border, whereas a keratoacanthoma usually presents as a rapidly growing nodule with a central area of keratinized material.
A 67-year-old man is evaluated for painful
lesion
inside his mouth.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Pemphigus vulgaris is a rare autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by blisters and erosions caused by detachment of adhesions between stratified squamous epithelial cells (acantholysis) on skin and mucous membranes. Oropharyngeal erosions are common and are frequently the presenting manifestation. Affected skin has flaccid blisters that generally develop on noninflamed skin; are readily broken; and progress to large, weeping, denuded areas. NSAIDs, rifampin, cephalosporins, captopril, and penicillamine have been associated with this condition.

A 37-year-old man is evaluated for the gradual onset of painless scrotal swelling. There is a smooth and resilient scrotal mass. Transillumination shows a translucent mass and the shadow of the testes. Focused ultrasonography of the scrotum is performed.
(Note that there is no sound for this
video
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is testicular hydrocele. Hydroceles are fluid collections between layers of the tunica vaginalis, visible on ultrasound as anechoic fluid surrounding the testicle. Examination typically reveals a tense, smooth, and transilluminating mass. Ultrasonography is used to confirm the diagnosis. This patient's ultrasound
shows
a normal testicle (
solid arrow
) with modest-sized hydrocele (anechoic fluid visible in near field,
dashed arrow
) and epididymis (extending left of testicle on the image,
double-lined arrow
). Spermatoceles are soft, rounded structures located within the epididymis, whereas varicoceles are dilated spermatic veins; neither appear as simple anechoic fluid on ultrasonography.

objective.__html: Diagnose testicular hydrocele using point-of-care ultrasonography.

children: A 44-year-old man is evaluated for chronic dermatitis, as
shown
. He is noted to have dandruff and has been treated for blepharitis.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is seborrheic dermatitis, which is characterized by pink-to-red skin lesions with greasy scales, crusts, and occasionally small pustules. The most common areas of involvement include the scalp (dandruff), nasolabial folds (as seen in this patient), cheeks, and medial eyebrows; the external auditory canals, skin behind the ears, and mid-chest may also be involved. Erythema of the eyelids associated with yellow crusting between the eyelashes (blepharitis) may be the only manifestation of seborrheic dermatitis in some patients.

title: Question 65

children: A 52-year-old woman is evaluated for hypertension.
Periorbital findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is xanthelasma, a form of xanthoma. Xanthomas are characteristic skin conditions associated with primary or secondary hyperlipidemias. Xanthomas are yellow or yellow-brown, orange, or reddish papules, plaques, or nodules. The type of xanthoma closely correlates with the type of lipoprotein that is elevated. The most common xanthoma types include eruptive, plane, xanthelasma, tuberous, and tendinous. Xanthelasma is a type of plane xanthoma localized to the periorbital area, most commonly on the upper medial eyelid, and is characterized by soft, nontender, nonpruritic plaques. Xanthelasma can occur without hyperlipidemia, particularly in older persons, but is often associated with familial dyslipidemias when seen in a younger person. These lesions are also a classic feature of primary biliary cirrhosis, a condition often associated with marked hypercholesterolemia. Eruptive xanthomas occur on extensor surfaces, as do tuberous xanthomas, which may also overlie joints. Tendinous xanthomas are associated with tendons, most commonly the Achilles tendon.

figureCredits: Image reproduced with permission from Lazarte J, Hegele RA. Regression of xanthelasmas with statin treatment in a normolipidemic patient [Letter].

children: Ann Intern Med
A 49-year-old man is evaluated for a growth on his
finger
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient most likely has verruca vulgaris (common warts). Verruca vulgaris are skin-colored verrucous papules that are keratotic and exophytic with thrombosed capillaries manifesting as black dots when the top of the wart is pared down. Other types of warts include verruca plana (flat warts), which are skin-colored, flat-topped papules; condyloma acuminata (genital warts), which are smooth to digitate papules that are skin-colored to tan; and verruca plantaris/palmaris (plantar/palmar warts), which are exo-/endophytic papules with thrombosed capillaries. Warts (verruca and condyloma) are caused by human papillomavirus.
A 50-year-old woman is evaluated for a pigment change in her
fingernail
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is melanonychia, a longitudinal brown pigmentation of the nail plate. Melanonychia can be a normal variant in persons with darker skin tones, but it may also occur as a result of systemic disease, medication, infection, or an underlying melanocytic lesion, such as malignant melanoma.
A 52-year-old woman is evaluated for a new-onset rash 5 days after taking amoxicillin. She has no other symptoms.
Representative skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is morbilliform (meaning measles-like) drug eruption, which is characterized by symmetrically arranged erythematous macules and papules, some discrete and others confluent. It typically involves the trunk and spreads to the limbs but spares the palms and soles. It occurs during the first or second week of exposure to an offending drug.

Photosensitive drug reactions tend to be limited to sun-exposed areas. Fixed drug reactions are typically circinate plaques with more limited involvement than is reflected in this image (typically the lips, genitals, face, or fingers). Although Stevens-Johnson syndrome may start as an erythematous macular rash on the trunk, the lack of systemic symptoms or mucocutaneous involvement makes this diagnosis unlikely.

title: Question 69

children: A 54-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine wellness examination. She is asymptomatic. An incidentally discovered oral finding is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has black hairy tongue. This benign condition is characterized by elongation and defective desquamation of filiform papillae and is more common in older men. It is sometimes associated with candidal infection, antibiotic use, Addison disease, niacin deficiency, or poor oral hygiene.
Acute development of a black hairy tongue secondary to penicillin use is
shown
in a different patient. Penicillin may have inhibited the growth of normal oral bacteria and permitted the overgrowth of fungi, resulting in the elongated, dark filiform papillae.

figureCredits: Images reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 47-year-old man develops skin pain, gritty eyes, oral lesions, and odynophagia 2 weeks after a course of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
Representative skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). The skin findings of TEN are painful, flat, purpuric, targetoid lesions that coalesce into dusky, poorly demarcated, confluent patches or may consist of confluent, tender erythema without identifiable individual lesions. The involved epidermis blisters and sloughs in sheets of skin, leaving behind denuded dermis. This image shows the erythema, sloughing skin, and a small area of denuded dermis next to the gluteal cleft.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is usually associated with more intense erythema than is seen in this image, but may have skin sloughing as well. Toxic shock syndrome has more limited skin findings, most frequently erythema and subsequent desquamation of the palms and soles.
A 22-year-old woman is evaluated for acute onset of eye pain associated with tearing and photophobia.
Ocular findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is corneal ulcer, as demonstrated by the whitish fluffy opacity at the 1 o'clock position (
arrow

). Patients with corneal ulceration usually have pain, a prominent foreign body sensation, and excessive blinking and tearing. Although not seen on this image, pus may be visible in the anterior chamber (hypopyon).
Anterior uveitis causes pain, redness, and hypopyon, but is not associated with the corneal changes
seen
in this image. Episcleritis and conjunctival hemorrhage cause a red eye, but are not painful.

title: Question 72

children: A 42-year-old man is evaluated for a chronic, slightly pruritic rash on his feet, as
shown
. One hand is also involved.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is tinea pedis. The chronic form of tinea pedis may present with silvery scale and dull erythema of the entire foot or with more localized annular erythematous and scaly patches. It can be accompanied by interdigital scaling and maceration or by blisters of the plantar arch, sides of the feet, and/or heel. It may itch or may be entirely asymptomatic. Tinea pedis can have a more acute form with 1- to 2-mm vesicles and can be extremely pruritic. In the two feet–one hand syndrome (as in this patient), one hand has a diffuse scaly appearance that is also fungal in nature; in this syndrome, tinea pedis typically precedes tinea manuum.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 73-year-old man is evaluated for a rapidly expanding cutaneous nodule.
Skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is keratoacanthoma, a form of rapidly growing skin tumor that is related to squamous cell carcinoma. Early lesions present as solitary, round nodules that grow over weeks. As the lesions mature, a central keratotic plug becomes visible and the lesion becomes craterlike. Keratoacanthomas may involute spontaneously over a period of weeks to months, but surgical excision is recommended because of the relationship with squamous cell carcinoma.
A 56-year-old woman is evaluated for asymptomatic purple bumps on her
vulva
that have gradually appeared over several years.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This patient has angiokeratomas of the vulva. Angiokeratomas are dilated, dark red, purple or black venules, approximately 4 mm in size, with a smooth, dome-shaped surface. These benign, asymptomatic lesions may bleed secondary to trauma.
A 57-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus is evaluated for right hip pain.
A radiograph of the hips is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is osteonecrosis of the hip. In early osteonecrosis, plain radiographs are often normal. The earliest plain radiograph changes
show
increased density of the femoral head (
white arrow
) followed by sclerosis and cyst development (
black arrow
). Subchondral radiolucency, known as the "crescent sign," is pathognomonic of osteonecrosis and represents subchondral collapse. Later stages reveal flattening or collapse of the femoral head.

MRI is 100% sensitive in the diagnosis of osteonecrosis and is a particularly important imaging modality when plain radiographs are normal but clinical suspicion is high. The T1-weighted MRI of a different patient
shows
subchondral fractures (T1 hyposignal) and flattening of the right femoral head characteristic of osteonecrosis.

objective.__html: Identify the radiographic findings of osteonecrosis of the hip.

title: Question 76

children: A 50-year-old malnourished man is evaluated for the skin findings
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

This image shows perifollicular petechiae of the skin caused by a vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy. Perifollicular petechiae of the skin occur around the skin's hair follicles as the name suggests and are small (≤2 mm) hemorrhages, which occur due to the frailty of the capillary walls. Other signs of vitamin C deficiency include coiled hairs, bruising, and impaired wound healing. Patients commonly develop gingivitis
shown
, as well as gingival hemorrhages, also caused by capillary frailty.

objective.__html: Diagnose perifollicular hemorrhage caused by vitamin C deficiency.

figureCredits: Images reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 39-year-old man is evaluated for a chronic pruritic skin condition involving the flexural surfaces of his wrist, arms, and legs.
Representative skin findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is atopic dermatitis. Adult atopic dermatitis characteristically involves the antecubital and popliteal fossae and flexural wrists. When atopic dermatitis is acute, the skin is pruritic and red with poorly demarcated, eczematous, crusted, papulovesicular plaques and excoriations. As the dermatitis becomes chronic, skin becomes lichenified with accentuated skin lines (lichen simplex chronicus) and, particularly in dark skin, hyperpigmented. In contrast, psoriasis most commonly presents as plaques on the extensor surfaces.
A 68-year old woman with chronic plaque psoriasis was treated with systemic glucocorticoids for an exacerbation of COPD. She developed an extensive new rash, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Erythroderma is the most likely diagnosis. Erythroderma is defined as redness and scaling of 80% to 90% of the body surface area. It primarily affects middle-aged men. The most common cause of erythroderma is a preexisting condition, although 40% of cases are idiopathic. Patients with a history of psoriasis who are treated with systemic glucocorticoids, often for another condition, may develop a widespread erythrodermic or pustular flare when the glucocorticoids are discontinued. The presence of alopecia, nail dystrophy, and thickening of the palms and soles are indicative of a long-standing underlying cause of erythroderma, such as cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, graft-versus-host disease, psoriasis, or pityriasis rubra pilaris. When erythroderma is acute, thick scaling of the palms and soles and nail changes do not occur. Erythroderma may be complicated by loss of fluid and heat across the inflamed skin.

title: Question 79

children: A 33-year-old woman is evaluated for a pigmented lesion on her
finger
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is an acral (pertaining to the limb) lentiginous melanoma. This patient has a pigmented lesion with a highly irregular border and variable coloration and is suspicious for a dysplastic nevus or acral lentiginous melanoma. Acral melanoma is the least common type of melanoma but is the most common presentation in persons of Asian descent and persons with dark skin. Clinically, an acral lentiginous melanoma appears as a dark brown to black, unevenly pigmented patch. It is typically found on palmar, plantar, and subungual surfaces.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 36-year-old man is evaluated for acute onset of a red eye. He is otherwise asymptomatic and has no other medical problems.
Ocular findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is episcleritis, or inflammation of the episclera, which lies between the conjunctiva and the sclera. Episcleritis is characterized by a red, flat or nodular, superficial lesion that allows visualization of the underlying vasculature. The lesion is usually not painful. Episcleritis is typically a self-limited condition, is not associated with systemic disease, and does not threaten vision. In contrast, scleritis is often associated with underlying inflammatory diseases, causes severe pain, and can threaten vision.

title: Question 81

children: A 25-year-old man is evaluated for a slightly pruritic rash that began as a single oval patch on his back.
Representative lesions on his lateral thigh are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Pityriasis rosea classically begins with a single, pink, 2- to 4-cm, thin, oval-shaped plaque with a thin collarette of scale at the periphery (known as the herald patch), as
shown

on a different patient. Similar but smaller plaques subsequently erupt within days to weeks, usually on the torso along skin cleavage lines in a “fir tree” distribution. Lesions may be asymptomatic or mildly itchy. Pityriasis rosea most commonly occurs during the spring or fall.

figureCredits: Image in critique reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 78-year-old man is evaluated in the office for a sudden peripheral vision defect, which was preceded by several days of increased numbers of floaters and flashes of light in the left eye.
Retinal examination findings are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The image demonstrates the characteristic folding and tearing of a retinal detachment. Retinal detachment is a separation of the neurosensory layer of the retina from the choroid beneath. Symptoms include diminished vision, photopsia (flashes of light), abrupt onset of multiple floaters in the vision, and metamorphopsia (wavy vision). These symptoms may be followed by a sudden peripheral visual field defect that resembles a black curtain and may progress across the entire visual field. A retinal tear and elevation of the surrounding retina may be visible on dilated funduscopy. Immediate evaluation by an ophthalmologist is indicated for surgical treatment.

title: Question 83

children: A 28-year-old woman with acute pharyngitis develops a rapidly expanding diffuse rash. The rash has a sandpaper-like texture, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is scarlet fever, which refers to the syndrome of an erythematous rash that occurs in association with
Streptococcus pyogenes

pharyngitis. The rash is a diffuse blanching rash consisting of 1- to 2-mm papules that give the rash a unique sandpaper-like texture when palpated. The rash begins and is most marked in the groin and axillae and then rapidly spreads to the trunk and extremities. Most patients have characteristic circumoral pallor and sparing of the palms and soles.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 29-year-old man is evaluated for the progressive development of painless
papules
on his penis.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is molluscum contagiosum. The infection causes a small, dome-shaped, smooth-surfaced papule that is skin colored, white-yellow, or pink and that may have a central umbilication, as
shown

. On close inspection, small, white inclusions may be seen. Most patients infected with molluscum contagiosum (poxvirus) are children. Adults may acquire the disease through sexual contact, resulting in genital and pubic lesions. Molluscum contagiosum usually resolves spontaneously in a few months but may persist and require destructive modalities or topical treatments. Immunosuppressed patients or patients with active atopic dermatitis may experience widespread, treatment-resistant disease.
A 22-year-old previously well woman is evaluated for the acute onset of painful sores on her right leg, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is ecthyma. Superficial, saucer-shaped ulcers with overlying crusts are the classic findings of classic ecthyma, which is a variant of impetigo. They almost always occur on the legs or feet and are usually caused by streptococci.
The name
ecthyma
may be confused with
ecthyma gangrenosum
, which is a more severe infection usually resulting from hematogenous spread and skin seeding of gram-negative rods, in particular
Pseudomonas,
in an immunocompromised host. Ecthyma gangrenosum
shown
is characterized by single or multiple cutaneous ulcers evolving from painless nodular lesions, with surrounding erythema progressing to central hemorrhage, ulceration, and necrosis.

title: Question 86

children: A 34-year-old woman is evaluated for the acute onset of a spreading skin lesion on the right forehead, as
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is impetigo, which is a superficial skin infection characterized by a yellowish, crusted surface. It may be caused by staphylococci or streptococci. If
Staphylococcus aureus
is the cause, secretion of exfoliative toxin may result in superficial blister formation (bullous impetigo). Diagnosis of impetigo is typically made based on clinical appearance.

figureCredits: Image reproduced from the CDC Public Health Image Library.

children: A 27-year-old man and his 8-year-old child are evaluated for an intensely pruritic rash on the hands.
The adult patient's hands are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Scabies (
Sarcoptes scabiei

) infestation causes intense itching and a papular or vesicular rash, commonly in the interdigital web spaces, as seen in this patient. Burrows are visible as short, serpiginous lines. Location in the interdigital webs, flexural surface of the wrists, penis, axillae, nipples, umbilicus, scrotum, and buttocks is diagnostic. Scabies infestation should be suspected whenever a patient and close contacts experience itching.
A 45-year-old man is evaluated for superior shoulder pain that is aggravated when he fastens his seat belt or when holding his arms outstretched. He is otherwise well.
A plain radiograph of the left shoulder is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is acromioclavicular degeneration. The radiograph of this patient's left shoulder shows evidence of degenerative changes of the left acromioclavicular joint consistent with acromioclavicular arthritis. As a synovial joint, the acromioclavicular joint may show the typical findings of osteoarthritis, including joint-space narrowing (
solid arrow
), subchondral sclerosis (
dashed arrow
), and osteophyte formation, as seen in this patient (left panel). A comparison of this patient's acromioclavicular joint with a normal acromioclavicular joint (right panel) is
shown
A 50-year-old man is evaluated for chronic changes in his
fingernails
Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these nail findings?
A classic diagnostic finding associated with psoriatic nails is nail pitting. Other characteristic features of nail psoriasis
shown
include distal onycholysis (separation of the nail plate from the underlying nail bed) (
arrows
) and splinter hemorrhages, which represent the Auspitz sign (punctate bleeding) in the nail bed. In addition, some patients may display the oil-drop sign (
circle
), which is characterized by a localized tan to brown discoloration of the nail.
In more severe forms of psoriatic involvement, there can be thickening and crumbling of the nails.

objective.__html: Diagnose nail changes due to psoriasis.

children: A 19-year-old woman is evaluated for generalized itching. Her eyebrows and eyelashes are
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is lice. This patient has phthiriasis palpebrarum, an uncommon complication of body lice that occurs on the eyelashes. Lice infestation is diagnosed by identifying crawling lice on the head (scalp, eyebrows, or eyelashes) or pubic hair. Louse egg cases (nits) are found sticking to the hair shaft in patients with lice, as
shown
in a different patient, and are generally easier to see than lice.
A 38-year-old woman develops a new generalized rash 1 day following administration of amoxicillin-clavulanate.
A portion of the rash is
shown
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The patient most likely has acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis, which is characterized by a rapid onset of a pustular rash following a medication exposure in a patient without a history of pustular psoriasis. Patients present with fever and erythema, and then develop myriad dense non-folliculocentric pustules, primarily in skin folds and on the trunk. The onset of the rash may be as soon as 1 day after exposure to the medication and up to a few days at most. Eighty percent of cases are caused by antibiotics.
